chapters.title: A twist in the tail
chapters.impact_statement: The Hawaiian bobtail squid and V. fischeri bacteria are the best of friends.
chapters.sidebar: Caitlin Brennan explains how the Hawaiian bobtail squid and certain bacteria work together

chapters.title: Up in the air
chapters.impact_statement: The receptors that allow insects to smell various chemicals probably evolved around the time they developed the ability to fly.
chapters.sidebar: Christine Missbach discusses the evolution of the sense of smell in insects in the eLife Podcast

title: February 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we learn more about sleep, super Spy chaperones, swimming bacteria, orphan genes and the neuroscience of birdsong.

chapters.title: And so to sleep
chapters.impact_statement: A protein called RYE – short for Redeye - has a central role in the regulation of sleep.
chapters.sidebar: Amita Sehgal talks about sleep in episode 9 on the eLife podcast

chapters.title: Flexible friends
chapters.impact_statement: Chaperones are proteins that help other proteins to fold properly, and being flexible makes them better at this task.
chapters.sidebar: James Bardwell talks about Super Spy chaperones in the eLife podcast

chapters.title: Twisting and turning
chapters.impact_statement: Bacteria employ a sophisticated method to ensure that they swim in a particular direction.
chapters.sidebar: Patrick Mears discusses how E coli swim in the eLife podcast.

chapters.title: The mystery of orphan genes
chapters.impact_statement: Orphan genes appear and disappear quite quickly in Drosophila, leaving the total number of genes roughly constant.
chapters.sidebar: Christian Schlötterer talks about orphan genes in the eLife podcast.

chapters.title: Lost in music
chapters.impact_statement: Songbirds stop listening to themselves when they start to sing.
chapters.sidebar: Richard Mooney discusses the neuroscience of birdsong in the eLife podcast.

title: January 2014
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss rats, ants, sharks and rays, and the pathogen that causes corn smut in maize.

chapters.title: Lost at sea
chapters.impact_statement: Over half of all shark and ray species are “threatened or near threatened” according to new estimates.
chapters.sidebar: Nicholas Dulvy describes the threats facing sharks and rays in episode 8 of the eLife podcast

chapters.title: Why rats don't rat on other rats
chapters.impact_statement: A rat will help another rat if it is familiar with that type of rat, even if it has not met the actual rat before.
chapters.sidebar: Peggy Mason talks about pro-social behavior in rats in episode 8 of the eLife podcast

chapters.title: Complex problem solved
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have worked out the structure of a protein complex that is involved in the destruction of T helper cells by HIV.
chapters.sidebar: James Hurley talks about the destruction of T helper cells in episode 8 of the eLife podcast

chapters.title: Into the maize
chapters.impact_statement: The pathogen that causes corn smut in maize employs a sophisticated strategy to increase its virulence.
chapters.sidebar: Regine Kahmann explains how corn smut attacks maize in episode 8 of the eLife podcast

chapters.title: Evolution at work in ants
chapters.impact_statement: The body shapes of queen ants and worker ants have evolved in different ways to reflect their different roles.
chapters.sidebar: Roberto Keller talks about the evolution of body shape in ants in episode 8 of the eLife podcast

title: December 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss the growing problem of drug resistance, severe brain damage, sugar versus sweetener, public goods dilemmas, and the evolution of translation machinery in cells.

chapters.title: Resistant to change
chapters.impact_statement: Resistance to antimicrobial drugs is not driven solely by the excessive use of these drugs.
chapters.sidebar: Steve Baker talks about drug resistance in episode 7 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Awakened by a sleeping pill
chapters.impact_statement: Why do some patients with severe brain injury become more alert after treatment with the sleeping pill zolpidem?
chapters.sidebar: Nicholas Schiff talks about severe brain injury in episode 7 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Life is sweet
chapters.impact_statement: How is the brain able to tell the difference between natural sugar and artificial sweetener?
chapters.sidebar: Jeff Friedman compares sugar and sweetener in episode 7 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Public goods dilemmas
chapters.impact_statement: Mathematical biologists are exploring the origins of cooperation in microbes.
chapters.sidebar: Benjamin Allen talks about cooperation between microbes in episode 7 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Change of expression
chapters.impact_statement: Rapid changes in the genes for transfer RNA have been observed in experiments on yeast.
chapters.sidebar: Yitzhak Pilpel talks about the evolution of protein translation machinery in cells

title: November 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss doing protein crystallography with electrons, the discovery of a receptor for carbon dioxide, new insights into arthritis, how the brain responds to a missing hand, and the best shape for whiskers.

chapters.title: Gently does it for crystallography
chapters.impact_statement: Very cold weak electron beams have been used to collect large numbers of diffraction patterns from protein microcrystals.
chapters.sidebar: Tamir Gonen talks about electron crystallography in episode 6 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: If your blood gets too acidic you will die
chapters.impact_statement: Carbon dioxide could be involved in processes as diverse as breathing, hearing and reproduction.
chapters.sidebar: Louise Meigh talks about carbon dioxide as a signaling molecule in episode 6 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: A gut feeling about arthritis
chapters.impact_statement: The gut microbiota of patients with rheumatoid arthritis is enriched in microbes belonging to the Prevotella genus.
chapters.sidebar: Dan Littman talks about gut bacteria and arthritis in episode 6 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: How the brain moves on
chapters.impact_statement: In individuals with a missing hand, the area of the brain responsible for that hand learns to control the remaining hand or the residual limb.
chapters.sidebar: Tamar Makin talks about the plasticity of the brain in episode 6 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Why do rodents have cone-shaped whiskers?
chapters.impact_statement: Conical whiskers allow mammals that live in tunnels and other enclosed spaces to learn more about their surroundings.
chapters.sidebar: Andrew Hires explains why rodent whiskers are conical in episode 6 of the eLife Podcast

title: October 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss how chimpanzees use conceptual metaphors, the hyperactivation of spermatozoa, the use of bacteria to estimate the time of death, stem cells and smoking, and a new type of bacteria.

chapters.title: Sperm BerserKers
chapters.impact_statement: Human sperm cells rely on an unusual type of potassium ion channel.
chapters.sidebar: Nadja Mannowetz talks about ion channels and sperm in episode 5 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: A microbial clock
chapters.impact_statement: Measurements of bacteria could have applications in forensic science.
chapters.sidebar: Jessicsa Metcalf talks about bacteria and forensic science in episode 5 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Welcome to Melainabacteria
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have found evidence for a new phylum of bacteria.
chapters.sidebar: Sara Di Rienzi describes evidence for a new phylum of bacteria in episode 5 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Tracking single stem cells
chapters.impact_statement: The epithelium that lines our airways is maintained by a population of basal cells.
chapters.sidebar: Sam Janes talks about stem cells and smoking in episode 5 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Chimpanzees get conceptual
chapters.impact_statement: The use of metaphorical concepts is not unique to humans.
chapters.sidebar: Ikuma Adachi talks about chimpanzees and social hierarchies in episode 5 of the eLife Podcast

title: September 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss how flatworms can grow new heads and tails, how photosynthesis has evolved over time, social interactions between mice, the properties of undead cells, and interactions between steroids and genes.

chapters.title: How flatworms regenerate tissue
chapters.impact_statement: How are organisms such as planarians able to grow new heads and tails?
chapters.sidebar: Peter Reddien talks about tissue regeneration in epsiode 4 of the eLife podcast

chapters.title: The evolution of photosynthesis
chapters.impact_statement: Computational techniques have shed fresh light on how C4 photosynthesis evolved from C3 photosynthesis.
chapters.sidebar: Julian Hibberd talks about the evolution of photosynthesis in episode 4 of the eLife podcast

chapters.title: Social interactions in mice
chapters.impact_statement: Mice that grow up in environments with lots of stimuli are less social and more territorial than mice that grow up in more spartan surroundings.
chapters.sidebar: Alon Chen talks about social interaction in mice in episode 4 of the eLife podcast

chapters.title: Undead cells and cell death at a distance
chapters.impact_statement: Cells undergoing programmed cell death release signals that trigger apoptosis in distant cells.
chapters.sidebar: Hermann Steller talks about "undead" cells in episode 4 of the eLife podcast

chapters.title: Turning transcription on and off in single cells
chapters.impact_statement: How much steroid is needed to switch on a single gene?
chapters.sidebar: Daniel Larson talks about watching transcription in single cells in episode 4 of the eLife podcast

title: August 2013
impact_statement: In this episode of the eLife podcast we discuss the cocktail party effect, how psuedogene RNA has a role in the immune response, new insights into the genetic origins of a common form of blindness, research into individual responses to the flu vaccine, and the origins of the tropical disease schistosomiasis.

chapters.title: The cocktail party effect
chapters.impact_statement: Neuroscientists are getting closer to understanding how people can distinguish where different sounds come from in noisy environments.
chapters.sidebar: Sundeep Teki talks about the cocktail party effect in episode 3 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Turning on pseudogenes
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have discovered a role for pseudogenes – which are thought to be dead genes – in regulating the immune response.
chapters.sidebar: Howard Chang talks about pseudogene RNA in episode 3 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Looking into blindness
chapters.impact_statement: Experiments with stem cells are shedding new light on the genetic origins of one of the most common forms of inherited blindness.
chapters.sidebar: Budd Tucker talks about a common form of blindness

chapters.title: How genes influence our response to the flu vaccine
chapters.impact_statement: Changes in gene expression could be used to predict whether individuals will respond successfully to the influenza vaccine.
chapters.sidebar: John Belmont explains how genes influence our response to the flu vaccine in episode 3 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Stem cells and tropical diseases
chapters.impact_statement: Genetic techniques are providing new insights into the origins of schistosomiasis, a tropical disease that is caused by parasitic flatworms.
chapters.sidebar: Phillip Newmark talks about the origins of schistosomiasis in episode 3 of the eLife Podcast

title: July 2013
impact_statement: In this issue of the eLife podcast we discuss plants performing arithmetic division, the evolutionary dynamics of cancer, single-molecule measurements in the immune system, why blood vessels don’t grow in the retina, how to make science count in government, a sensor for ammonium, and the evolution of gene regulation.

chapters.title: Plants performing arithmetic division
chapters.impact_statement: Plants use chemical reactions to calculate the rate at which they can use up their stores of starch during the night and still have some left at sunrise.
chapters.sidebar: Martin Howard and Alison Smith talk about plants performing arithmetic division in episode 2 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: The evolutionary dynamics of cancer
chapters.impact_statement: A mathematical model has predicted that cancer drugs given in combination are more effective than the same drugs given in sequence.
chapters.sidebar: Martin Nowak talks about the evolutionary dynamics of cancer in episode 2 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Why blood vessels don't grow in the retina
chapters.impact_statement: Researchers have identified a receptor that prevents blood vessels forming in the outer retina—a process that can lead to blindness—by sequestering a crucial growth factor.
chapters.sidebar: Balamurali Ambati explains why blood vessels don't form in the retina in episode 2 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: Single-molecule measurements in the immune system
chapters.impact_statement: Single-molecule measurements in living cells have revealed that a single foreign peptide is able to activate a single T cell.
chapters.sidebar: Geoff O'Donoghue talks about performing single-molecule measurements in the immune system

chapters.title: And there's more
chapters.impact_statement: eLife features editor Peter Rodgers discusses a topical Point of View article by Ian Boyd, chief scientific adviser to the Department of the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs in the UK, plus research articles on a sensor for measuring extracellular ammonium and a study of the evolution of gene regulation in yeast.

title: June 2013
impact_statement: Welcome to the first eLife podcast, which covers topics as diverse as the origins of multicellularity, what modern sequencing technology can tell us about the potato famines of the 1840s, the discovery of the receptor for the hepatitis B and D viruses, the effect of fog on the behaviour of car drivers, and the evolution of chromatin.

chapters.title: The origins of multicellularity
chapters.impact_statement: Extremely low concentrations of a molecule produced by bacteria can cause single-celled organisms to form colonies, which suggests that bacteria might have influenced the origin of multicellularity in animals
chapters.sidebar: Rosie Alegado talks about the origins of multicellularity in episode 1 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: What modern sequencing technology can tell us about the potato famines of the 1840s
chapters.impact_statement: The strain of P. infestans that caused the Great Famine in the late 1840s has been identified by sequencing the genomes of samples collected in the 19th century.
chapters.sidebar: Sophien Kamoun and Hernan Burbano talk about genomics and potato famines in episode 1 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: All about eLife
chapters.impact_statement: eLife deputy editor Fiona Watt explains why eLife was launched and what it hopes to achieve.
chapters.sidebar: eLife deputy editor Fiona Watt talks about the launch of eLife and what the journal hopes to achieve

chapters.title: A receptor for the hepatitis B and D viruses
chapters.impact_statement: The identification of a functional receptor for the hepatitis B and D viruses could lead to new strategies for tackling these diseases.
chapters.sidebar: Wenhui Li talks about the discovery of the receptor for the hepatitis B and D viruses in episode 1 of the eLife Podcast

chapters.title: The effect of fog on car drivers
chapters.impact_statement: Virtual reality experiments show that motorists slow down when driving in fog, but they speed up when visibility is reduced equally at all distances.
chapters.sidebar: Paolo Pretto talks about the effect that fog has on our perceptions of speed while driving

chapters.title: The evolution of chromatin
chapters.impact_statement: Similarities between the chromatin in archaea and eukaryotes suggest that it might have been involved in gene regulation before its role in DNA packaging evolved.
chapters.sidebar: Corey Nislow talks about the evolution of chromatin in episode 1 of the eLife Podcast
